Career Profile

I like to call myself a full stack data-scientist, as I am interested in every aspect of modern data-science. From cleaning small data files to large cloud databases, from training a linear model to a deep neural net, from a Matplotlib visualisation to a responsive web application.

Experiences

Service engineer

2011 - 2013
Elliot Turbo

After my graduation as energy engineer, I wanted to travel. So I joined Elliot Turbo as service engineer. I traveled in the US, Europe and the Middle-East to repair and overhaul 80MW compressors.

Wind turbine maintenance engineer

2013 - 2015
Belwind

After experiencing the oil and gas industry, I wanted to work on renewables. As maintenance engineer, I spend quite a lot of time on the Belgian offshore wind turbines. I dived into the (financial) reporting to the management and shareholders. I became an Excel guru and played with numbers every day. I realized however that I lacked some knowledge and took a year off to study statistics.

Data scientist

2016 - 2017
KBC data lab

After studying statistics, I joined the big-data lab of a large Belgian bank (KBC). It was a perfect hands-on environment to master all the techniques I learned in the master of statistics. Surrounded by phd levels, I learned about more or less every single data related technology.

Founder - Data scientist

2017 - 2019
Rockestate

I made my master thesis in statistics about enriching house listings with open data to predict the price of each house in Belgium. I continued to work on it during the weekends, and in 2017 I convinced two associates to start up the company Rockestate. Multiple banks and insurers now use the Rockestate curated data-lake and products. I left the company because after four years it is was time for something new.

Freelance Data scientist

2020-201
The Jobcoach

I developed an online personality test used as a lead generation tool by The Jobcoach. You can try it out on test.jobmatchter.com. The test is done by around 30 persons per day, and has a conversion rate of around 10%. I did everything myself, I trained and deployed the algorithm, and developed the front-end of the website.

Projects

Rockestate - Zimmo Prijswijzer - Zimmo, a belgian online real estate platform, asked Rockestate to build an online tool to help users predict the price of their house. We have build the entire backend. The statistical model is based upon a geo-spatial regression technique, called Geographically Weighted Regression. I originally developed this model during my master thesis
Names I Like - A couple of years ago, all of my friends started to have kids (I have two kids of my own by now). I thought I could help my girlfriend predicting which name they were going to pick. This hobby project turned into a website with over 100k visitors per year. The backend is based on a recommender algorithm based upon matrix factorization, made famous by the Netflix competition. You can try it out on www.namesilike.com
